Board time is 19:00, your access level is Third Class
On Earth the elections of the United Nations Economical Intervention Council (UNEIC) are over. New executive is Igelstan Kleidsten.
His agenda against the impacts of climate change and for the rapid resettlement of injured people to colonies convinced the council.
In his inaugural speech he underlined the importance of improving the logistical infrastructure needed for resettlements from urban centres to young colonies.
"Rapidly growing outposts of humanity will solve the challenges on Earth and also solve the initial difficulties of facilities in space," he declared at the end of his speech.
Ceres is the largest object in the main asteroid belt that lies between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter. With a diameter of 940 km, Ceres is the largest of the belts` asteroids.
The geology of Ceres is driven by ice and brines, with an overall salinity of around 5%.
One of the most spectacular pheonomena on Ceres are cryovolcanos that errupt ice and minerals to the surface.
Have a nice day!

The main purpose of initial colonisation of Ceres was to create the first head quarter for operations in asteriod belt. Therefore the converted transport ship Spark was sent on a non-returning mission into the void.
After arrival in Ceres orbit the crew landed the vessel and restructured it to a fixed base. The first colony on an asteroid was founded as planned.
The mission is an example for human bravery and successful joint ventures of the United Nations with private space companies.
Shortly after the planetary landing, work began on an underground tunnel system which offers maximum protection against the dangers of the void.
At first the crew quarters and scientific facilities were dug into the iced ground of "Miss Cerry", like the colonists called their new home.
The crew quarters of that time became storage room for precious minerals and today Cerians reside in comforable crew areas deeper in the mantle
The sickness that some colonists had contracted recently was contained and does not pose a threat to ongoing operations.
The station management would like to point out again that all patients are well again and that there are no indications for an extraterrestrial origin of the disease.
